Pre-requisites
BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOMEDICAL SCIENCES 2022-23
HESA Cost Centres
Biosciences
Blurb
Overview
This module explains the chemical principles that underpin biological processes and pharmacological understanding.

It is designed for students with A-level Chemistry, or equivalent pre-university qualifications in chemistry, and is required for Biochemistry and Pharmacology students, as well as those who wish to take subsequent modules in pharmacology, structural biology or medicinal chemistry.

The lectures will be supplemented with on-line resources; students will be given guided reading, and regular formative assessment workshops and online tests will enable students to evaluate their understanding of the module.

The module will be assessed by formative and summative online tests.
Educational Aims
This module aims to develop in students:

Knowledge and understanding of the chemical principles that underpin biological processes;

Awareness of the chemical processes that are required to understand pharmacological principles;

The ability to evaluate this knowledge and apply it to solve problems, in biochemistry, pharmacology and biomedicine.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The Biochemistry and Pharmacology programmes, and at UoL require students to have studied chemistry to A level or equivalent standard. The Biological Chemistry module is designed to build on this background, and the chemical content of the Year 1 modules, especially LIFE101 and LIFE102 (which is designed for all students) to develop chemical understanding and analytical skills to support later modules in structural and mechanistic biochemistry, medicinal chemistry and pharmacokinetics. The module may also be taken by C130 or C100 students with the appropriate chemical background to equip them to study some of these later modules as part of their general programmes.
Outline Syllabus
Thermodynamics: 3 sessions + 1 workshop
Systems, First Law, Second Law ;
Reactions/cells/organisms as thermodynamic systems;
Entropy, enthalpy, free energy;
Standard Free energy –actual free energy;
ATP and hexokinase in erythrocytes: free energy relations and energy coupling;
Equilibrium constant, relationship to standard free energy change.

Organic Structure and Mechanism: 9 sessions + 3 workshop
Structure
Bonding (resonance)
Drawing molecules
Functional groups/naming
Acid/Bases
Isomers/L-D stereoisomers
Examples of key reactions, including
- substitution
- carbonyl (acetal/glycosidic bond
- Hydrolysis/condensation (peptides/oligos)
- Oxidation/Reduction
- Catalytic triads

Water: 2 sessions + 1 workshop
H-bonding;
Polarization;
Solvation;
H-phobic effect, hydropathy/protein folding, base stacking, membranes;
Dissociation, Kw;
Acids, bases, Ka, pKa;
Amino acids;
Henderson-Hasselbalch;
Buffers;

Kinetics: 4 sessions + 1 workshop
Exponential decline and half life;
Radioactivity, drug clearance;
Rates of chemical reactions;
First order, second order;
Rate constants, rate equations;
Relationship to ∆G, equilibria, binding and Kd;
Chemical catalysis;
Enzyme catalysis;
ES complex model/steady state;
Michaelis –Menten;
Link to ligand binding;
Enzyme inhibition;
Competitive, non-competitive, mixed examples.

Spectroscopy: 3 sessions + 1 workshop
Absorption, emission; fluorescence principles;
UV-vis, IR;
Mass spectrometry;
Basic NMR.

Bioinorganic Chemistry: 2 sessions
Metal ions and coordination chemistry;
Iron in proteins: Haems; P450; FeS centres;
Copper and manganese ions in proteins.

Bioenergetics: 2 sessions + 1 workshop
Understanding energy conversion in biological systems; reduction potential, electron transfer and proton gradients.
Teaching and Learning Methods
The technical and problem solving nature of the material in the module syllabus, the module lends itself to the idea of active learning (Liverpool Curriculum Framework), including flipped classroom approaches in some cases, where video lecture segments presented asynchronously are supplemented with more discursive discussion of the material in live synchronous workshops, where calculations and problems are discussed in formative sessions. Assessments are authentic (Liverpool Curriculum Framework) , in that they involve real-world problem solving and calculations.

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
Assessment will involve two online formative tests that will involve interpretation and application of the methods learned throughout the module, and which will be practiced in the workshop sessions. For each of the two tests, students can complete the first 10% multiple times, before undertaking the final 90% as a single timed attempt. The first, stage of each test supplies immediate feedback, while the second stage ensures a high participation rate.

There will also be a summative online test during the mid-semester assessment period and the end of semester assessment period, with a combination of multiple choice and other automated questions types. These assessments will be authentic (Liverpool Curriculum Framework) in that they have a large component of problem solving and analytical questions, rather than simple recall.

Reassessment strategy:
There will be re-sit opportunity in the normal reassessment period, to be submitted on Canvas. The questions will be different to those used in the original tests. The mark will be capped at 40.

Exam: there is a resit opportunity. A combination of multiple choice and short-answer questions different to those used in the original exam. The mark will be capped at 40.

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Health and Safety
None risk outside those associated with working on campus. No lab-based experimental work.
Admin
Marked for Rollover
No
Replace Future Instances
No
Notes
LIFE 245 has been created to move the previous Biological Chemistry module, LIFE104 from S2, Year 1, to S1, Year 2, with relative little modification. LIFE104 was a very challenging Year 1 module. Its move to the start of Year 2 is in response to other programme-level changes designed to rationalise the teaching of molecular biology to a number of programmes in Year 1, rather than a requirement to increase the level of challenge associated with the module. Although a small amount of chemistry material has been introduced in LIFE102 in Year 1, Semester 2, taken by almost everyone who will take this module (except XJTLU students in the Biochemistry programme), this will be accommodated by small changes in the curriculum of LIFE245. It is not the case that the overall standard and the assessment of LIFE245 needs to change appreciably from that of LIFE104 – it is doing essentially the same job as it was before – giving the chemical background for biochemists and pharmacologists, as well as other interested students from general programmes, for them to engage with structural and mechanistic biology, and medicinal chemistry in later modules in Year 2. Staff and students on programmes that use this module were consulted via minuted meetings and an online survey.

Its move to the start of Year 2 is in response to other programme-level changes designed to rationalise the teaching of molecular biology to a number of programmes in Year 1, rather than a requirement to increase the level of challenge associated with the module. Although a small amount of chemistry material has been introduced in LIFE102 in Year 1, Semester 2, taken by almost everyone who will take this module (except XJTLU students in the Biochemistry programme), this will be accommodated by small changes in the curriculum of LIFE245. It is not the case that the overall standard and the assessment of LIFE245 needs to change appreciably from that of LIFE104 – it is doing essentially the same job as it was before – giving the chemical background for biochemists and pharmacologists, as well as other interested students from general programmes, for them to engage with structural and mechanistic biology, and medicinal chemistry in later modules in Year 2. Staff and students on programmes that use this module were consulted via minuted meetings and an online survey.

HESA Cost Centres
Biosciences
Blurb
Overview
This module explains the chemical principles that underpin biological processes and pharmacological understanding.

It is designed for students with A-level Chemistry, or equivalent pre-university qualifications in chemistry, and is required for Biochemistry and Pharmacology students, as well as those who wish to take subsequent modules in pharmacology, structural biology or medicinal chemistry.

The lectures will be supplemented with on-line resources; students will be given guided reading, and regular formative assessment workshops and online tests will enable students to evaluate their understanding of the module.

The module will be assessed by formative and summative online tests.
Educational Aims
This module aims to develop in students:

Knowledge and understanding of the chemical principles that underpin biological processes;

Awareness of the chemical processes that are required to understand pharmacological principles;

The ability to evaluate this knowledge and apply it to solve problems, in biochemistry, pharmacology and biomedicine.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The Biochemistry and Pharmacology programmes, and at UoL require students to have studied chemistry to A level or equivalent standard. The Biological Chemistry module is designed to build on this background, and the chemical content of the Year 1 modules, especially LIFE101 and LIFE102 (which is designed for all students) to develop chemical understanding and analytical skills to support later modules in structural and mechanistic biochemistry, medicinal chemistry and pharmacokinetics. The module may also be taken by C130 or C100 students with the appropriate chemical background to equip them to study some of these later modules as part of their general programmes.
Outline Syllabus
Thermodynamics: 3 sessions + 1 workshop
Systems, First Law, Second Law ;
Reactions/cells/organisms as thermodynamic systems;
Entropy, enthalpy, free energy;
Standard Free energy –actual free energy;
ATP and hexokinase in erythrocytes: free energy relations and energy coupling;
Equilibrium constant, relationship to standard free energy change.

Organic Structure and Mechanism: 9 sessions + 3 workshop
Structure
Bonding (resonance)
Drawing molecules
Functional groups/naming
Acid/Bases
Isomers/L-D stereoisomers
Examples of key reactions, including
- substitution
- carbonyl (acetal/glycosidic bond
- Hydrolysis/condensation (peptides/oligos)
- Oxidation/Reduction
- Catalytic triads

Water: 2 sessions + 1 workshop
H-bonding;
Polarization;
Solvation;
H-phobic effect, hydropathy/protein folding, base stacking, membranes;
Dissociation, Kw;
Acids, bases, Ka, pKa;
Amino acids;
Henderson-Hasselbalch;
Buffers;

Kinetics: 4 sessions + 1 workshop
Exponential decline and half life;
Radioactivity, drug clearance;
Rates of chemical reactions;
First order, second order;
Rate constants, rate equations;
Relationship to ∆G, equilibria, binding and Kd;
Chemical catalysis;
Enzyme catalysis;
ES complex model/steady state;
Michaelis –Menten;
Link to ligand binding;
Enzyme inhibition;
Competitive, non-competitive, mixed examples.

Spectroscopy: 3 sessions + 1 workshop
Absorption, emission; fluorescence principles;
UV-vis, IR;
Mass spectrometry;
Basic NMR.

Bioinorganic Chemistry: 2 sessions
Metal ions and coordination chemistry;
Iron in proteins: Haems; P450; FeS centres;
Copper and manganese ions in proteins.

Bioenergetics: 2 sessions + 1 workshop
Understanding energy conversion in biological systems; reduction potential, electron transfer and proton gradients.
Teaching and Learning Methods
The technical and problem solving nature of the material in the module syllabus, the module lends itself to the idea of active learning (Liverpool Curriculum Framework), including flipped classroom approaches in some cases, where video lecture segments presented asynchronously are supplemented with more discursive discussion of the material in live synchronous workshops, where calculations and problems are discussed in formative sessions. Assessments are authentic (Liverpool Curriculum Framework) , in that they involve real-world problem solving and calculations.

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
Assessment will involve two online formative tests that will involve interpretation and application of the methods learned throughout the module, and which will be practiced in the workshop sessions. For each of the two tests, students can complete the first 10% multiple times, before undertaking the final 90% as a single timed attempt. The first, stage of each test supplies immediate feedback, while the second stage ensures a high participation rate.

There will also be a summative online test during the mid-semester assessment period and the end of semester assessment period, with a combination of multiple choice and other automated questions types. These assessments will be authentic (Liverpool Curriculum Framework) in that they have a large component of problem solving and analytical questions, rather than simple recall.

Reassessment strategy:
There will be re-sit opportunity in the normal reassessment period, to be submitted on Canvas. The questions will be different to those used in the original tests. The mark will be capped at 40.

Exam: there is a resit opportunity. A combination of multiple choice and short-answer questions different to those used in the original exam. The mark will be capped at 40.

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Health and Safety
None risk outside those associated with working on campus. No lab-based experimental work.

Its move to the start of Year 2 is in response to other programme-level changes designed to rationalise the teaching of molecular biology to a number of programmes in Year 1, rather than a requirement to increase the level of challenge associated with the module. Although a small amount of chemistry material has been introduced in LIFE102 in Year 1, Semester 2, taken by almost everyone who will take this module (except XJTLU students in the Biochemistry programme), this will be accommodated by small changes in the curriculum of LIFE245. It is not the case that the overall standard and the assessment of LIFE245 needs to change appreciably from that of LIFE104 – it is doing essentially the same job as it was before – giving the chemical background for biochemists and pharmacologists, as well as other interested students from general programmes, for them to engage with structural and mechanistic biology, and medicinal chemistry in later modules in Year 2. Staff and students on programmes that use this module were consulted via minuted meetings and an online survey.
